description: From Middle English sissen, perhaps from Middle Dutch sissen, cissen or Middle Low German sissen (“to hiss; buzz”), of imitative origin. Cognate with Dutch sissen, German Low German zissen, German zischen.

verbs.description: siss (third-person singular simple present sisses, present participle sissing, simple past and past participle sissed)

entries.meaning: (US, colloquial, intransitive) To make a hissing sound.
examples: a flat-iron hot enough to siss when touched with a wet finger
